intro: Ophiorrhiza jackiana, commonly known as the Jack's mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant belonging to the family Rubiaceae. It is characterized by its small, leathery leaves and is typically found growing on the branches of host trees in tropical and subtropical regions. The plant has a short stem and produces small, white or yellowish flowers, followed by capsule fruits containing tiny seeds. Its root system is adapted for parasitic attachment to host plants, allowing it to absorb water and nutrients. Ophiorrhiza jackiana plays a role in the ecological dynamics of its habitat, contributing to the biodiversity of forest ecosystems.
